SafetyInspectionBy: Iowa Department of Ag and Landstewship

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical and plumbing codes. This facility complies with Iowa Fertilizer Laws
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the juridictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/Theft(Methamphetamines). Provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around plant perimeter to reduce the potential of vehicular damage.
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow limiters-what in the traade is called an excess flow valve. Breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote shut-off valve installed at the storage tank.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspections and routine preventative maintenance and repairs
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pumps, piping, valves, and safety equipment.
_prev_prog_2.Description: The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of anhydous ammonia fromthe storage vessel(s) to nurse tank. In doing so, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail.  Repairs can be made before they become problematic.  Employees are annually trained to recognize hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia. This training is performed annually and for all new hires which includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant and follow-up observations to determine their individual comprehension and understanding for the new hire.  Finally, the company routinely invites local fire and ems departments to visit the site.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Board of Directors, management and employees of Heartland Co-op are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, County Emergency Management, the Iowa Department of Natural Resources and/or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to the public and the environment.

The primary activity at the facility is the distribution of products to farmers.  The fertilizer product, anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and distributed for direct application as a nutrient for crop production.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in tanks designed for this purpose.

This facility follows the provisions of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 20 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" and our state regulations covering anhydrous ammonia.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia during the last five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, has there been any accidental releases resulting in off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage, or environmental damage.

The felicity has a written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38.  We do not plan to have our employees respond to a major release.  If a large release of anhydrous ammonia takes place at our facility, the response action is to evacuate the area of the spill and call 911 and all applicable emergency response numbers listed in our Emergency Action Plan.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the conditions of the facility.  There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding the storage or the use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
